channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: 越南儿童的教育体系是世界上最好的教育体系之一。这对经济也有帮助👇。
item.description:
Vietnamese children go through one of the best schooling systems in the world. That has helped the economy too https://t.co/OvqRGLZP6G 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 比尔-克林顿曾开玩笑说，中国永远无法控制互联网。然而，中国在很大程度上成功地创建了一个为自己服务的互联网。现在，它需要指挥一种新技术--人工智能🎧。
item.description:
Bill Clinton once joked that China would never be able to control the internet. Yet it largely succeeded in creating an internet that serves its own purposes. Now there is a new technology it needs to command—artificial intelligence https://t.co/hiPyBH2a8x 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 数百万中国人将毕生积蓄投入到可能永远无法建成的房产中。1843 》杂志采访了心怀不满的准居民 👇 。
item.description:
Millions of Chinese people have ploughed their life savings into properties that may never get built. 1843 magazine talks to disgruntled would-be residents https://t.co/R6TVUskRf9 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 他信-西那瓦（Thaksin Shinawatra）在与泰国强大的当权派斗争了几十年之后，似乎也加入了他们的行列。这位前总理已成为打击泰国民主人士的工具👇。
item.description:
After decades fighting Thailand’s powerful establishment, Thaksin Shinawatra appears to have joined it. The former prime minister has become a tool for nobbling Thai democrats https://t.co/ShQOV3G0gG 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 香港越来越不像一个国际城市 👇
item.description:
Hong Kong is becoming less of an international city https://t.co/4CzSnl0Km5 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 唐纳德-特朗普(Donald Trump)在全国范围内领先尼基-黑利(Nikki Haley)约60个百分点，在她领导了六年的南卡罗来纳州领先30个百分点。一位在任期内如此受欢迎的州长为何表现如此糟糕？我们为您解释👇。
item.description:
Donald Trump leads Nikki Haley by some 60 points nationally and by 30 points in South Carolina, the state that she led for six years. How did a governor who was so popular during her tenure come to perform so poorly? We explain https://t.co/puQ0KowL2F 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 通货紧缩是被消灭了，还是正在反弹？在世界各地，尤其是在美国，通胀的回升有可能推迟利率的下调 👇
item.description:
Has inﬂation been vanquished, or is it bouncing back? Everywhere, and especially in America, its resurgence threatens to delay cuts to interest rates https://t.co/WPtrg1n4CC 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 是什么驱使人们离开中国城市，前往山区？一本新书探讨了为什么越来越多的城市人参与到一种被称为 "返古 "的潮流中👇。
item.description:
What is driving people out of Chinese cities to the mountains? A new book examines why growing numbers of urbanites are partaking of a trend known as fugu (a return to old ways) https://t.co/jxpPwehirb 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 芬太尼现在几乎可以肯定是 18 至 49 岁美国人的最大杀手。经济学家可能终于找到了危机的令人信服的解释👇。
item.description:
Fentanyl is now almost certainly the biggest killer of Americans between the ages of 18 and 49. Economists may have at last found a convincing explanation for the crisis https://t.co/Ng6BXFULga 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 日本的典型性别角色--工薪族丈夫和家庭主妇--是在战后长期繁荣时期形成的。现在，日本男性正面临身份危机。
item.description:
Japan’s archetypal gender roles—the salaryman husband and stay-at-home mum—were cemented during the country’s long post-war boom. Now Japanese men are facing an identity crisis https://t.co/el5jRBQwC1

Photo: Getty Images pic.twitter.com/xHuF20Db9m

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 为了在共和党领导层的反对声中推进乌克兰援助，美国众议院的立法者们考虑采用解除请愿的方式。我们将在 "美国政治大全"👇中解释这一立法手段。
item.description:
To advance Ukraine aid amid opposition from Republican leadership, lawmakers in America’s House of Representatives have considered using a discharge petition. We explain the legislative manoeuvre in our A to Z of US politics https://t.co/zjrHmp1GKz 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 为什么北约对美国人重要？关于 "制衡"： @Gottemoeller 为北约辩护🎧 一个创始国退出北约🎧 我们的副主编谈唐纳德-特朗普的言论
item.description:
Why should NATO matter to Americans? On “Checks and Balance”: https://t.co/J3KJY8svJ5

🎧 @Gottemoeller defends the alliance
🎧 When a founding member stepped back from NATO
🎧 Our deputy editor on Donald Trump’s comments

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 美国最高法院正准备处理网络平台的监管问题。干涉社交媒体公司是否违反第一修正案？ 👇
item.description:
America’s Supreme Court is preparing to tackle regulations of online platforms. Does meddling with social media companies violate the First Amendment? https://t.co/FcBTAeesWW 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 习近平将密切关注美国总统大选。但无论美国政坛如何分裂，对中国的敌意现在已是两党的事，而且根深蒂固👇。
item.description:
Xi Jinping will be watching America’s presidential election very closely. But however divided American politics may be, hostility towards China is now a bipartisan matter, and deeply entrenched https://t.co/lQEDLTOLrM 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 租房便宜还是买房便宜？我们的分析显示了近年来美国大部分地区买房和租房的相对成本是如何被颠覆的👇。
item.description:
Is it cheaper to rent or buy property? Our analysis shows how the relative costs of buying and renting have been upended throughout much of America in recent years https://t.co/dWYgBNPLbU 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 澳大利亚正在射杀野马。拖延已久的野马捕杀行动正引发争议👇。
item.description:
Australia is shooting its wild horses. And the long-delayed brumby cull is proving controversial https://t.co/3f4SJLaWNs 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 印度最高法院的独立性如何？尽管最高法院权力巨大，但它很少挑战政府 👇
item.description:
How independent is India’s Supreme Court? Despite its enormous powers, it rarely challenges the government https://t.co/NexqvRJuFr 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 11 月，美国人将选出他们的下一任总统。经济学人》正在追踪这场角逐。关注最新民调，阅读关于两位主要候选人的简短指南，并标记关键的选举日历日期👇。
item.description:
In November Americans will elect their next president. The Economist is tracking the contest. Follow the latest polls, read short guides on the two main candidates, and mark key electoral-calendar dates https://t.co/kuV4XJK8SJ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 乔治亚-梅洛尼回忆起自己装扮成《指环王》中人物的情景；由于个子矮小，她最后总是装扮成霍比特人。幻想文学与意大利极右翼之间有什么联系？1843》杂志深入探讨了这段漫长而奇特的历史。
item.description:
Giorgia Meloni recalls dressing up as characters from “The Lord of the Rings”; as she was short she always ended up as a hobbit.

What is the link between fantasy literature and the Italian far-right? 1843 magazine delves into this long and curious history https://t.co/aI9azvY0Ry

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 23, 2024

item.title: 本周的 "Money Talks "播客：人工智能可以改变教育，但让教育技术走进课堂是个令人头疼的问题 👇
item.description:
On this week’s “Money Talks” podcast: AI could transform education, but getting edtech into classrooms is a headache https://t.co/0YdLIqX5oR 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 23, 2024

item.title: 唐纳德-特朗普（Donald Trump）在民调中对乔-拜登（Joe Biden）的领先优势可能比看上去的要小。如果只考虑最高质量的民调，共和党的优势就会消失👇。
item.description:
Donald Trump’s polling lead over Joe Biden may be smaller than it looks. If you consider only the highest-quality polls, the Republican’s advantage melts away https://t.co/lRPFOnmW1P 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 23, 2024

item.title: 俄罗斯重整军备、乌克兰局势恶化、唐纳德-特朗普可能重返白宫，这些因素交织在一起，将欧洲推向了几十年来最危险的关头。
item.description:
The confluence of Russia’s rearmament, Ukraine’s deteriorating position and Donald Trump’s possible return to the White House have brought Europe to its most dangerous juncture in decades https://t.co/6MjeZMUTvJ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 23, 2024

item.title: 介绍 El Boletín，我们关于拉丁美洲的新每周通讯。经济学人》的订阅者可在此注册，了解塑造这个迷人而复杂地区的各种力量 👇
item.description:
Introducing El Boletín, our new weekly newsletter on Latin America. Subscribers to The Economist can sign up here to understand the forces shaping a fascinating and complex region https://t.co/RWoFSQCbLF 👇

item.title: 纽约的房价高得惊人。事实上，它是北美最昂贵的城市。看看您的城市排名如何 👇

item.title: 台积电在日本建厂的运气比在美国好。刁钻的工人和繁琐的手续使其在亚利桑那州的工作进展缓慢👇。
item.description:
TSMC is having more luck building in Japan than in America. Truculent workers and red tape have slowed its efforts in Arizona https://t.co/pKCffJPA8H 👇

item.title: 市场给了年轻人一手烂牌。他们可以打得更好。他们应该这样投资 👇

item.title: 去年，有 4.3 万名来自俄罗斯、4.2 万名来自印度和 2.4 万名来自中国的移民过境。而在 2021 年，这一数字分别为 4100 人、2600 人和 450 人👇。
item.description:
Last year 43,000 migrants from Russia, 42,000 from India and 24,000 from China made the crossing. That’s up from 4,100, 2,600 and 450, respectively, in 2021 https://t.co/OwROJY4v1h 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 23, 2024
